item.title: Wicked: For Good‚Äòs Scarecrow Reveal Has Fans Both Horny And Horrified
item.content:encoded:
I haven‚Äôt seen the full Wicked stage play, but I was already well aware of the twists and turns we‚Äôd see in Wicked: For Good. The musical sequel covers the events of the play‚Äôs second act, and it includes several direct ties to the original Wizard of Oz story. As such, I was braced for it to reveal the brainless Scarecrow, but I was not prepared for how the guy would actually look when on screen, and neither were most people, it seems, as the reveal has caught fans off guard.

In the Wicked continuity, Fiyero (Jonathan Bailey, People‚Äôs Sexiest Man Alive), the carefree prince who starts growing a conscious after he meets Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo), becomes the Scarecrow. He starts off as a dashing, charismatic narcissist, but as Fiyero grows to care for Elphaba and her battle for animal rights, he turns against the Wizard‚Äôs fascist regime and becomes a fugitive with the Wicked Witch. 

Later in the film, he is captured by the Wizard‚Äôs guards and tortured. Elphaba, desperate to save her lover, casts a spell to keep him from dying or feeling any pain. We don‚Äôt see Fiyero‚Äôs face for almost the entirety of the second half of the movie because For Good goes out of its way to obscure it and hide his identity, but we unknowingly see the back of his head a few times. That‚Äôs because Elphaba‚Äôs spell turned him into the Scarecrow who accompanies Dorothy in The Wizard of Oz. 

We don‚Äôt actually see Fiyero as the Scarecrow until the final moments of For Good, and while an eagle-eyed Wizard of Oz fan may have caught onto this twist when he was strung up on a cross in a cornfield during Elphaba‚Äôs spell, plenty of first-time viewers were genuinely shocked by this reveal, not only because of Fiyero‚Äôs dark fate, but because Bailey straight up looks like a patched together version of Ryan Reynolds in his Scarecrow look.

My entire theater burst out laughing when they saw the Scarecrow's design

‚Äî 5 DAYS UNTIL DON CHEADLE'S BIRTHDAY (@Schaffrillas) November 21, 2025

out mogged the wicked for good scarecrow pic.twitter.com/CHKems9MTo

‚Äî üëπ (@tummyhxrts) November 22, 2025

also happy to report fiyero looks chopped asf as the scarecrow like even tin man boq is out mugging him pic.twitter.com/lrDdCGEHAQ

‚Äî gelphie conquers all (@aIicentinchains) November 18, 2025

While some might be unsettled by Fiyero‚Äôs new face, others aren‚Äôt going to let some straw and burlap keep them from recreating that one scene from Pearl. Others are praising Wicked: For Good‚Äôs use of practical makeup and effects to pull off the Scarecrow‚Äôs look, as well as Ethan Slater‚Äôs take on the film‚Äôs terrifying, revenge-crazed Tin Man.

the worst part of that fiyerocrow spoiler is that he looks so weird in the pic i thought he was UGLY and HE'S NOT????

‚Äî laura (@leaftraveler_4) November 21, 2025

let‚Äôs not forget that the scarecrow and tin man in wicked: for good were prosthetics and makeup‚Ä¶ incredible!!! pic.twitter.com/7SCCM80vvz

‚Äî lauren (@hoenymoomavenue) November 21, 2025

WHAT IF THIS WAS MY LAST STRAW pic.twitter.com/S601Afz67S

‚Äî julie‚Å∑ is still defending fiyeraba (@juliesayit) November 23, 2025

It would have been a bit of a copout if Fiyero‚Äôs Scarecrow look was pretty much just Bailey‚Äôs face with a filter on it. I have a lot of issues with Wicked‚Äôs paper-thin connective tissue between the show and the Wizard of Oz story, but I have to give the crew props for making its transformed leading men appropriately horrifying. Nevertheless, thirst finds a way.

item.title: Wild Arc Raiders Moments Like These Show Why People Love It
item.content:encoded:
Extraction shooters are eager to take everything away from you. And though Arc Raiders has proven to be a more friendly approach with its multiple paths of progression, dying at the end of a successful run still sucks. Getting pushed 99 percent of the way to failure and then surviving, however, is a feeling like no other.

As more folks pour into Arc Raiders‚Äô servers to hopefully extract and craft their way to glory, they‚Äôre capturing epic victories snatched from the jaws of defeat and sharing them as reminders that even when you think you‚Äôre about to lose everything, luck (or a guardian angel) can always intervene.

Last night, I came across one such clip from a few days ago of what would seem to be an unfortunate PvP instance during a Night Raid (usually a preem opportunity to score some great loot if you know where to look) suddenly turned on its head:

Gunned down by a rando, Reddit user Over_here_vibin prepares to get sent back home with nothing to show for it. Then his assailant gets sniped in the head literally out of nowhere. Turns out, some folks must‚Äôve been watching nearby and were quick to put down the threat while also escorting Over_here_vibin to extraction.

Fun fact learned from this video? If you don‚Äôt have a defib to revive a stranger, you can use bandages to temporarily stabilize them, which is often enough to see someone successfully get out.

Humans aren‚Äôt your only potential allies, though. As spotted by Games Radar, another fantastic clip sees someone gunned down literally as they‚Äôre standing in the elevator. If you‚Äôve played any amount of Arc Raiders, then you know getting shot in the elevator is literally one of the worst feelings (especially as it often happens right as the doors are closing, meaning your assailant doesn‚Äôt even have time to loot your body and just offed you seemingly just for the fun of it).

This is Beautiful ‚ù§Ô∏è #ArcRaiders
üé•RedRiser pic.twitter.com/RkAYVow0rL

‚Äî ARC Now (@ArcRaidersNow) November 21, 2025

As luck would have it, a Rocketeer (one of the most menacing of airborne threats in the game thus far) not only interrupts the execution animation, but knocks the assailant out of the elevator with a rocket, downing them in the process. While it is possible the assailant might‚Äôve been able to crawl over and call in a new elevator, it‚Äôs likely their decision to shoot someone in the back led to their loss.

My feeds are full of situations like this. It just goes to show that, until the game literally sends you back to Speranza, don‚Äôt give up. A friendly human, or Arc, might just save the day.

Oh, and if you run solos, please carry defibs for your fellow Raiders!



https://kotaku.com/arc-raiders-extract-rat-elevator-revive-defib-2000646958

Call it a race car, a thoroughbred, a rocket, or any other analogy you want, and the M5 iPad Pro lives up to it. item.title: Battlefield 6 Players, Please Capture Control Points
item.content:encoded:
Later this week, Battlefield 6‚Äòs conquest mode and some of its maps will be free to play across all platforms. That means an influx of new players. So now seems like a good time to ask everyone, even the people already playing EA‚Äôs blockbuster online FPS, to please capture control points in Conquest. Please. I‚Äôm begging you.

I‚Äôve been playing a lot of Battlefield 6 since it launched in October. And I‚Äôve had a great time with it. The FPS is easily my favorite Battlefield in a few years and will likely be a game I return to a lot in 2026. But whenever I play Conquest, the franchise‚Äôs iconic mode that‚Äôs been around since the OG Battlefield 1942, I get frustrated by how many players seem not to understand the point of the mode. That point being: Capture control points, hold and defend them, and if needed, take them back from the enemy. Hold more points, and your team will win faster. Let them control the battlefield, and you‚Äôll lose just as quickly.

Sounds simple enough, yet I‚Äôve lost a Conquest match and skimmed the scoreboard afterward countless times, just to spot half or more of my team with zero captures.

Now, I understand that some people are sniping and aren‚Äôt capping points. Fine. And some are using tanks and aircraft to support the team and won‚Äôt have as many captures as some other players or me. I get that, too. My problem is that so many players who aren‚Äôt sniping or using tanks seem to just‚Ä¶ not take control points.

I‚Äôve watched players run into the first control point at the start of a match and capture it, then just run around the next one, never going in to cap it or help their team hold it. These aren‚Äôt snipers either, but support or assault players. Other times, I see people run to an enemy base, help fight and clear it, and then leave when it‚Äôs neutralized but not fully capped. Or some players will cap a base and then never leave it.

I don‚Äôt care if you only get three kills. I don‚Äôt care if you a dozen times. As long as you are helping our team cap points, push forward when it makes sense, and fall back when needed to defend, I‚Äôll be happy. And you‚Äôll likely get more XP and be higher up on the scoreboard, too, as Battlefield 6 greatly rewards teamplay and objective support over kills. So help your team win, get to the top of the leaderboard, and have a fun time by capturing control points in Battlefield 6, okay? Please.

item.title: Roborock Decided Money Doesn‚Äôt Matter, Q10 S5+ Robot Vacuum Drops 50% Off With 10,000Pa Suction
item.content:encoded:
Roborock has become the premium brand in robot vacuums with their latest flagships such as Qrevo CurvX and Saros 10R crossing the $1,000 threshold even with Black Friday discounts. But here‚Äôs the thing: the Roborock Q5 S10+ is currently sitting at an all-time low of $259 on Amazon, down from its original $549 price tag, and it‚Äôs flying off the shelves. This model packs serious technology into a mid-range package ‚Äì think 10,000Pa suction power, a self-emptying station that holds 70 days worth of debris, and a sonic mopping system that scrubs 3,000 times per minute. The kind of deal that makes you wonder if someone in Roborock‚Äôs pricing department made a mistake.

See at Amazon

Best in Class Vacuum Cleaner

First of all, the 10,000Pa suction power puts this vacuum in the same league as models costing twice as much. That level of suction pulls embedded pet hair out of carpet fibers, grabs crumbs from hardwood floor crevices, and handles the kind of everyday mess that accumulates a lot quicker than you‚Äôd like to admit. The HyperForce technology behind this suction isn‚Äôt just a marketing term: it‚Äôs the difference between a robot that pushes debris around and one that actually removes it.

The self-emptying station completely changes the way you interact with the vacuum. You are looking at a 2.7L dust bag, able to hold up to 70 days of dirt and debris, which essentially means that you can forget about emptying for over two months. This is where pet owners will appreciate it more than anyone because pet hair fills up the standard robot vacuum bins in a matter of days. The station will automatically empty the robot after each cleaning session so you‚Äôll never need to deal with those pesky clouds of dust or tangled hair when manually emptying a bin.

The VibraRise 2.0 mopping system is where this vacuum starts to feel like a premium product. Dual-zone sonic vibration scrubs floors up to 3,000 times per minute, which is enough force to handle dried spills and stuck-on messes that regular robot mops just smear around. The mopping module automatically lifts 8mm when it detects carpet, so you‚Äôre not dealing with wet carpets or having to manually remove mop pads before running a cleaning cycle. You can adjust mopping intensity through the app depending on how dirty your floors are, giving you control without requiring manual intervention.

The smart carpet detection uses ultrasonic technology to identify when the vacuum moves onto carpet from hard floors. Detecting carpet, it lifts the mopping modules and automatically increases suction power for a deeper cleaning. This dual response ensures that the carpets get the aggressive cleaning they require while protecting them from water damage. It‚Äôs reliable enough that you can run cleaning cycles while away from home with no fear of returning to soaked rugs.

Navigation on this vacuum relies on PreciSense LiDAR technology which scans 360¬∞ to create detailed maps of your home. The system supports multi-level mapping, meaning if you have a two-story house, the vacuum remembers the layout of both floors and can plan efficient cleaning routes for each level. With ReactiveTech obstacle avoidance, structured light technology is used to detect objects in real time and navigate around them, meaning fewer situations where it gets stuck and more complete cleaning coverage without needing to pre-clean before the robot vacuum cleans.

At $259, this vacuum delivers technology that was reserved for $500+ models just a couple of years ago. Roborock‚Äôs reputation for build quality means you‚Äôre not sacrificing reliability to hit this price point, and the fact that it‚Äôs selling in huge volumes on Amazon suggests plenty of people have figured out this is an unusually good value.

item.title: The Most Underrated Tomb Raider Game Came Out 25 Years Ago Today
item.content:encoded:
When people recall their favorite Tomb Raider games, it‚Äôs often focused on which was their first. For me, that was Tomb Raider II, and as such, it remains very special. For others, it‚Äôs the wonderful opener to Crystal Dynamics‚Äô era of the franchise, Tomb Raider Legends. And for many more, it‚Äôll be one of the more recent entries, like 2018‚Äôs Shadow of the Tomb Raider. But for all the reminiscing and celebrating, there‚Äôs one entry that seems to get little love, despite being one of my absolute favorites at the time, and to replay today: Tomb Raider: Chronicles. It turns 25 years old today.

There is a perennial issue for both games and movies, which I call Critic Fatigue. It doesn‚Äôt matter how good a series may be, nor how increasingly popular it might be among audiences: at a certain point, critics seem to believe it‚Äôs their role to be sick of something. ‚ÄúUh, another Avengers movie? I hate it just for existing!‚Äù ‚ÄúMore Assassin‚Äôs Creed?! It‚Äôs time for it to be taken down a peg or two!‚Äù It‚Äôs like it‚Äôs their collective job to punish a franchise for having too many entries. That happened astoundingly harshly to Tomb Raider at the turn of the century.

Business is boobing

Obviously, the first three Tomb Raider games were a phenomenon. From 1996 to 1998, the original trilogy received international hype that today is hard to even conceive. It was a messy combination of a worthwhile celebration of three genuinely fantastic video games and the lecherous misogyny of the late-90s era. The reason an entire generation bought 3DFX cards, Lara Croft championed and emboldened the third-person action genre, and had rather large boobies. So yes, there was a lot to be frustrated by, especially in Lara‚Äôs home country of the UK, where ‚Äúlad mags‚Äù ruled supreme with their soft-porn photography and lifestyle articles. This aspect was so blatantly exploited by publisher Eidos that there was always an ‚Äúofficial‚Äù Lara Croft model, despite these people never appearing in movies, TV shows, or any other actually extant tie-in media. Instead, the likes of Rhona Mitra, Ellen Rocche, and Nell McAndrew would show up on the covers of those lad mags with multi-page photo shoots within, and on cardboard cut-outs in every gaming store. (And on the covers of many a gaming magazine.) It‚Äôs pretty embarrassing to look back on, not least remembering how Nell McAndrew was hypocritically fired from the role after posing for Playboy.

But for all the squirm-inducing marketing, the games remained fantastic. They still are. Then, in 1999, came Tomb Raider: The Last Revelation, and the tide started to turn. Critic Fatigue was due to kick in, and you could smell the backlash coming. The Last Revelation was more of the same, and for some reason, more of something we previously loved stops being good enough after a while, and scores came in lower. It wasn‚Äôt helped by a crappy Dreamcast port, but there was still enough residual love for the franchise that The Last Revelation escaped the brunt of the kickback. That was reserved for‚Äîin my opinion‚Äîa better game.

Putting the fun in funeral

The Last Revelation‚Äôs ending deserved far more criticism. The game, during which you watched Lara Croft die some 40 billion times, ended with a cutscene in which Lara Croft died. A pyramid falls on top of her. ‚ÄúReload then!‚Äù I remember saying to the screen at this ridiculous forced ending, reloading to see if I‚Äôd made a mistake. But nope, she was dead. It was extremely silly, but it happened for a reason. Core, the developers of the games, were sick of making Tomb Raider games. It was hoped that by killing her, the developers would be free to make something else. It didn‚Äôt work, and Eidos demanded more.

However, it also set up a superb conceit for the fifth game, Tomb Raider: Chronicles. Rather than beginning with Lara in the middle of some improbable heist, then bringing us back to her manor to start a new series of international adventures, Chronicles began with Croft‚Äôs funeral. That‚Äôs something, right! And of course, everyone was expecting the immediate reveal, that having the Pyramid of Giza squish her flat turned out not to be so serious, and reports of her death were greatly exaggerated. Except that‚Äôs not what happened at all. Instead, post-funeral, Lara‚Äôs butler Wilson invites two of her close compatriots back to the manor for a drink. Together, the three begin to reminisce about their friend, recalling adventures that had yet to be seen in the games. And that‚Äôs what you play! Four stories, in completely unique settings, at different stages in Lara‚Äôs life‚Äîincluding as a teenager.

The result was almost all great! Each of the four chapters was a distinct game, with enormous variety in setting, from haunted islands to modern, high-tech skyscrapers, via an abandoned submarine, delivering the intricate puzzles and acrobatic antics we‚Äôd come to expect from developers Core. That no one involved in the game apparently wanted to make it really didn‚Äôt come through, perhaps via some sort of involuntary competence, or as a result of breaking it into small chunks that felt less oppressive to create. I can imagine if someone had just played the first four games through in a row and then instantly started on this fifth, they could be thoroughly sick and tired of Lara and her formula. But giventhat  a year went by between each entry, I really want to push back against this ‚Äúfatigue‚Äù argument.

Backlashing out

No matter Chronicles‚Äò merits, they wouldn‚Äôt matter. The backlash was due, many critics were ready to put Lara in her place for having the temerity to keep returning. Scores came in hard and harsh, with even IGN almost hitting its lowest possible score of 6. EDGE dished out a mauling 4, while the usually supplicant Official PlayStation Magazine joined in with a 5. But as you read through those reviews (or the residual summaries remaining on the internet), they all praise the game, celebrate its great level design, recognize it as a good example of a Tomb Raider game, but then penalize it for‚Ä¶existing? That OPM review, that 2.5 star score, described the game as ‚Äúthe best sequel in the series thus far,‚Äù albeit then claiming that all the other games ‚Äúdownright sucked.‚Äù The same magazine gave TR II a 9, then the third game 7. The fourth game, that one got a 10.

IGN‚Äòs review couldn‚Äôt make my argument any better. The 25-year-old article had the strapline, ‚ÄúLara Croft‚Äôs last adventure on PlayStation is also her very best. Still, it‚Äôs just more of the same.‚Äù There it is! The whole point, perfectly encapsulated! How dare this game be the best example of a thing?

The review goes on to say that the matter of annual releases ‚Äúturned what could have been one of gaming‚Äôs most cherished franchises into one of the most reviled.‚Äù Most reviled! For the crime of carrying on being good too often. The article also praises the game for its four distinct chapters, offering ‚Äúthe greatest amount of diversity in play style and atmosphere,‚Äù then calls the fourth story ‚Äúone of the best Tomb Raider levels ever.‚Äù

A huge part of this reaction, as indeed is the case in most other examples, is leveling complaints at the latter entry that should have been raised from the start. So Chronicles was repeatedly berated across reviews for its control issues, and indeed the games‚Äô silly combat, even though these aspects were almost always overlooked in the rush of excitement for, er, the first three games. The best example of the series so far, having the same faults as the poorer examples in the past, makes the most recent game the worst? That seems to be the rule.

And yes, of course, I‚Äôm not naive. Having the same control issues five games in is crappy and should be dealt with. But given they were given a critical pass the first four times, and the games sold eighty million-billion-squillion copies despite them, there‚Äôs not a great deal of incentive being put before the developers to prioritize them. It is, in a large part, a failure of criticism.

It‚Äôs the same reason Bethesda gets to release half-finished games with barely functioning UIs, because why would the developer bother to do otherwise? It knows it‚Äôll get a round of 9s and 10s from every outlet despite it, and given the company releases new games every decade rather than every year, these consistent issues don‚Äôt seem to amount to ‚Äúfatigue.‚Äù It took an actively boring game, Starfield, for any hint of that backlash to appear.

The fallen angel

I‚Äôm here to say that I loved Tomb Raider: Chronicles, despite the litany of flaws that haunted the entire franchise up until that point. I played Tomb Raider games on PC, with one hand on a game controller and the other on my keyboard, because this was the only way the crummy control issues were overcome. That worked for Chronicles as well as it worked for Tomb Raider II, and if anything, I was used to it by then. It was a splendid game, despite the malaise behind its creation, because‚Äîas so many identified at the time‚Äîit featured some of the best levels in the series!

The irony that it was Chronicles that received the backlash when the borderline unplayable Tomb Raider: The Angel of Darkness was just three years away isn‚Äôt lost on me either. Both games were developed simultaneously, the former a reluctant sop to the publisher, the latter a whole fresh start for Core. But after years of delays and brutal development issues, Angel of Darkness was atrocious. Lara was close to uncontrollable, the enemy AI was abysmal, and the game quickly became a laughing stock. And it reviewed the same as Chronicles, because it was new! It was fresh! So it had to be interesting. This time, reviews went, ‚ÄúWhile the game is so broken as to be functionally useless, it has new graphics!‚Äù (To be abundantly fair to IGN, after just picking on them, the site gave it a good kicking with a score lower than some thought it could reach: 5.3.)

Chronicles is included in Aspyr‚Äôs recent remake, Tomb Raider IV-VI Remastered, although given my experience with the gruesome mess of the first three, I‚Äôm not convinced it‚Äôd be the best way to play‚Äîdefinitely stick to the original graphics and controls. You can also pick it up paired with The Last Revelation from GOG for under $9, and then go crazy on PCGamingWiki, getting it all patched up for modern machines.

I say it‚Äôs worth it! Ignore those fatigue-ridden naysayers. It‚Äôs OK for something to be good five times in a row.

item.title: Amazon Practically Giving Smart Plug Away, 50% Off Makes It Cheaper Than Regular Plugs
item.content:encoded:
Amazon is practically giving away its smart plug at a price that barely exceeds what you‚Äôd pay for a basic outlet adapter: At $12, down from $24, this connected device costs roughly the same as a dumb power strip from the hardware store.

This Black Friday, Amazon slashed prices across all its own-brand products by approximately 50%, selling at zero margin to drive ecosystem adoption. The smart plug exemplifies this aggressive strategy and offers voice control and automation at a price that removes every excuse for not starting your smart home journey.

See at Amazon

Voice Control That Changes Your Daily Routine

The Alexa integration adds voice commands to any device that has a physical on/off switch. Tell Alexa to turn on your coffee maker from bed, and hot coffee waits when you reach the kitchen. Command the lamp in your living room to turn off from the couch. Turn on a fan in another room without walking there. These minor conveniences compound throughout your day into proper quality-of-life improvements.

Setup takes literally minutes and requires no technical knowledge whatsoever. Plug the Smart Plug into any outlet, open the Alexa app on your phone, and follow the simple, on-screen prompts. The plug connects automatically to your 2.4GHz WiFi network. You then name the device based on what you‚Äôre controlling, such as ‚Äúbedroom lamp‚Äù or ‚Äúcoffee maker.‚Äù It takes less than five minutes from box to working smart device.

No smart home hub requirement removes the additional hardware cost that plagued earlier smart home adoptions. It directly connects your Smart Plug to your WiFi and communicates with Alexa over the cloud. You avoid buying expensive hubs like SmartThings or dedicated Zigbee coordinators. The Alexa app manages all your Smart Plugs from one interface.

Routine automation turns disparate smart devices into cohesive systems that react intelligently. Create a morning routine that starts the coffee maker at 7 AM, turns on bathroom lights, and starts playing the news on your Echo. A bedtime routine might turn off all the lights, smart lock the doors, and drop the thermostat. Leaving home triggers an away routine to power down everything non-essential. These are scheduled automations that happen independently of you and creates the smart home experience most people envision when they first hear about connected devices.

Alexa+ capabilities give you much more natural interactions with your smart home. You can set routines without having to open the app, using voice commands for actions that power multiple devices at once, such as saying, ‚ÄúAlexa, it‚Äôs movie night,‚Äù to activate all the smart lighting in the room and turn on TV-connected devices. You can be a lot more casual about what you are asking for without needing to follow strict command structures. It all feels less robotic compared to earlier smart home controls, which required you to say things in a very specific way.
